questions.question: Which type of access point requires individual configuration and management?
questions.explanation: Autonomous APs are self-contained and must be configured individually. Lightweight APs are centrally managed by a WLC.
questions.exam_tip: Remember: Autonomous = Independent = Individual configuration required
questions.reference: CCNA v1.1 - 1.1d Access Points - Autonomous Architecture

questions.question: What protocol do lightweight access points use to communicate with a wireless LAN controller?
questions.explanation: CAPWAP (Control And Provisioning of Wireless Access Points) is the protocol used by lightweight APs to communicate with the WLC. It replaced the older LWAPP protocol.
questions.exam_tip: CAPWAP is the current standard. LWAPP is the legacy protocol it replaced.
questions.reference: CCNA v1.1 - 1.1d Access Points - CAPWAP Protocol

questions.question: Which two statements about CAPWAP are true? (Choose two)

options.A: The control tunnel uses UDP port 5246
options.B: The data tunnel uses TCP port 5247
options.C: Both tunnels are encrypted by default
options.D: The control tunnel is encrypted by default
options.E: CAPWAP tunnels use TCP for reliability

questions.explanation: CAPWAP uses UDP (not TCP) for both tunnels. Control tunnel (UDP 5246) is encrypted by default. Data tunnel (UDP 5247) is NOT encrypted by default but can be encrypted with DTLS.
questions.exam_tip: Memorize: UDP 5246 (control, encrypted) and UDP 5247 (data, not encrypted by default)
questions.reference: CCNA v1.1 - 1.1d Access Points - CAPWAP Protocol Details

questions.question: What is the default operational mode for a lightweight access point?
questions.explanation: Local mode is the default mode for lightweight APs. In this mode, the AP provides a BSS for clients to associate with and forwards all traffic through CAPWAP tunnels to the WLC.
questions.exam_tip: Default = Local. This is a common exam question.
questions.reference: CCNA v1.1 - 1.1d Access Points - Operational Modes

questions.question: A network administrator needs to deploy access points at a remote branch office. The APs must continue to provide wireless service even if the WAN link to the central WLC fails. Which AP mode should be configured?
questions.explanation: FlexConnect mode allows APs to locally switch traffic between wired and wireless networks if connectivity to the WLC is lost. Local mode requires WLC connectivity for data forwarding.
questions.exam_tip: FlexConnect = Survives WLC failure. This is the #1 use case for remote sites.
questions.reference: CCNA v1.1 - 1.1d Access Points - FlexConnect Mode

questions.question: Which lightweight AP mode is dedicated to detecting rogue wireless devices and can send de-authentication frames to disassociate rogue clients?
questions.explanation: Monitor mode APs do not offer a BSS for clients. They are dedicated to receiving 802.11 frames to detect rogue devices and can send de-authentication messages. Rogue Detector mode listens on the wired network only.
questions.exam_tip: Monitor = Wireless monitoring. Rogue Detector = Wired monitoring.
questions.reference: CCNA v1.1 - 1.1d Access Points - Monitor Mode

questions.question: In a split-MAC architecture, which three functions are handled by the lightweight access point? (Choose three)
questions.explanation: In split-MAC architecture, the AP handles time-sensitive operations: RF transmission/reception, encryption/decryption, and sending beacons. The WLC handles management functions like authentication, RF management, and QoS policies.
questions.exam_tip: AP = Real-time/Fast tasks. WLC = Management/Smart tasks.
questions.reference: CCNA v1.1 - 1.1d Access Points - Split-MAC Architecture

questions.question: What type of switch port should a lightweight access point connect to?
questions.explanation: Lightweight APs connect to access ports because they tunnel all traffic to the WLC via CAPWAP. They don't need trunk ports because they don't locally switch VLANs. Autonomous APs require trunk ports.
questions.exam_tip: Lightweight = Access port. Autonomous = Trunk port. This is frequently tested.
questions.reference: CCNA v1.1 - 1.1d Access Points - Network Integration

questions.question: An enterprise has deployed 100 access points across a campus, all broadcasting the same SSID 'CorpWiFi'. What type of service set is this?
questions.explanation: An ESS (Extended Service Set) consists of multiple APs broadcasting the same SSID, creating one logical wireless network. A BSS is a single AP. An MBSS is a mesh network.
questions.exam_tip: Multiple APs + Same SSID = ESS. This enables seamless roaming.
questions.reference: CCNA v1.1 - 1.1d Access Points - Service Sets

questions.question: What identifies a single access point's wireless coverage area?
questions.explanation: BSSID (Basic Service Set Identifier) is the MAC address of an AP's radio and uniquely identifies each AP. SSID is the network name and can be shared by multiple APs in an ESS.
questions.exam_tip: BSSID = MAC address = Unique per AP. SSID = Network name = Shared across ESS.
questions.reference: CCNA v1.1 - 1.1d Access Points - Service Sets

questions.question: Which three connection states are valid during the 802.11 client association process? (Choose three)
questions.explanation: The three valid 802.11 states are: (1) Not authenticated, not associated (initial), (2) Authenticated, not associated (after auth request/response), (3) Authenticated and associated (fully connected). A client cannot be associated without being authenticated first.
questions.exam_tip: You can't be associated without being authenticated. State C is impossible.
questions.reference: CCNA v1.1 - 1.1d Access Points - Association Process

questions.question: In a mesh network deployment, what is the access point that connects to the wired network called?
questions.explanation: In an MBSS (Mesh Basic Service Set), the RAP (Root Access Point) is connected to the wired network. MAPs (Mesh Access Points) are the other APs that wirelessly connect to form the mesh.
questions.exam_tip: RAP = Root = Wired connection. MAP = Mesh = Wireless connection.
questions.reference: CCNA v1.1 - 1.1d Access Points - MBSS

questions.question: What do access points periodically send to advertise their presence and available wireless networks?
questions.explanation: Beacon frames are periodically broadcast by APs (typically every 100ms) to advertise the BSS and its capabilities. Clients use passive scanning to listen for beacons.
questions.exam_tip: Beacons = AP broadcasts. Probe requests = Client sends.
questions.reference: CCNA v1.1 - 1.1d Access Points - Association Process

questions.question: Which lightweight AP mode should be used for wireless packet capture and analysis with tools like Wireshark?
questions.explanation: Sniffer mode dedicates the AP to capturing 802.11 frames and sending them to analysis software like Wireshark. The AP does not offer a BSS for clients in this mode.
questions.exam_tip: Sniffer = Packet capture. Monitor = Rogue detection.
questions.reference: CCNA v1.1 - 1.1d Access Points - Sniffer Mode

questions.question: A network engineer needs to identify sources of RF interference affecting wireless performance. Which AP mode is dedicated to spectrum analysis across all channels?
questions.explanation: SE-Connect (Spectrum Expert Connect) mode dedicates the AP to RF spectrum analysis on all channels. It can send data to software like Cisco Spectrum Expert for collecting and analyzing interference sources.
questions.exam_tip: SE-Connect = Spectrum analysis = Finding interference sources.
questions.reference: CCNA v1.1 - 1.1d Access Points - SE-Connect Mode

questions.question: What authentication method do lightweight APs and WLCs use to verify each other's identity?
questions.explanation: Lightweight APs and WLCs authenticate each other using X.509 standard digital certificates. This ensures only authorized APs can join the network and prevents rogue APs from connecting to the WLC.
questions.exam_tip: X.509 certificates = Mutual authentication between AP and WLC.
questions.reference: CCNA v1.1 - 1.1d Access Points - CAPWAP Security

questions.question: Which architecture is recommended for a small coffee shop with one access point?
questions.explanation: For small deployments (1-5 APs) where centralized management isn't necessary, autonomous APs are the most cost-effective solution. A WLC would be overkill and add unnecessary cost.
questions.exam_tip: Small/simple deployment = Autonomous. Large/complex = Lightweight + WLC.
questions.reference: CCNA v1.1 - 1.1d Access Points - Architecture Selection

questions.question: Which three are advantages of lightweight AP architecture over autonomous APs? (Choose three)

options.F: Individual AP configuration via web GUI

questions.explanation: Lightweight architecture advantages include: centralized management (configure all APs from WLC), seamless roaming (clients maintain connection), and automatic RF optimization. However, it has higher upfront cost (WLC required) and doesn't support individual web GUI configuration.
questions.exam_tip: Lightweight = Management, Scalability, Roaming. Autonomous = Simple, Low cost.
questions.reference: CCNA v1.1 - 1.1d Access Points - Architecture Comparison

questions.question: A company has 500 access points managed by a central WLC. An administrator needs to change the wireless password for the corporate SSID. How many devices need to be reconfigured?
questions.explanation: With lightweight architecture, configuration is centralized on the WLC. Changing the password on the WLC automatically pushes the update to all managed APs via CAPWAP. No individual AP configuration needed.
questions.exam_tip: This demonstrates the key benefit of centralized management in lightweight architecture.
questions.reference: CCNA v1.1 - 1.1d Access Points - Centralized Management

questions.question: Which scanning method has a wireless client send probe requests and listen for probe responses from access points?
questions.explanation: Active scanning has the client send probe requests on all channels and listen for probe responses from APs. Passive scanning involves the client listening for beacon frames sent by APs.
questions.exam_tip: Active = Client sends probes. Passive = Client listens for beacons.
questions.reference: CCNA v1.1 - 1.1d Access Points - Association Process

questions.question: An AP in Rogue Detector mode has its radio disabled but listens to wired network traffic to correlate with information from the WLC. What protocol messages does it primarily monitor on the wired network?
questions.explanation: Rogue Detector mode APs listen for ARP messages on the wired network. By correlating MAC addresses from ARP with the list of suspected rogue devices from the WLC, they can detect if a rogue AP is physically connected to the wired network.
questions.exam_tip: Rogue Detector uses ARP correlation to confirm rogues on wired network.
questions.reference: CCNA v1.1 - 1.1d Access Points - Rogue Detector Mode

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of the Bridge/Mesh AP mode?

options.C: Create wireless links between sites over long distances

questions.explanation: Bridge/Mesh mode is used to create wireless connections between sites, similar to outdoor bridge functionality. It's used when running physical cables between locations is difficult or expensive.
questions.exam_tip: Bridge/Mesh = Wireless WAN link between sites.
questions.reference: CCNA v1.1 - 1.1d Access Points - Bridge Mode

questions.question: What must a wireless client be in order to send traffic through an access point?
questions.explanation: A client must be both authenticated AND associated to send traffic through the AP. Authentication alone is not sufficient - the client must complete the full association process.
questions.exam_tip: Both conditions required: authenticated AND associated.
questions.reference: CCNA v1.1 - 1.1d Access Points - Association States

questions.question: A network architect is designing a wireless deployment for a large warehouse where running Ethernet cables to all AP locations is cost-prohibitive. Which three requirements must be met for a mesh network? (Choose three)

options.A: At least one RAP with wired network connection
options.B: All APs must have dual radios
options.C: MAPs must use the same channel for client and backhaul traffic
options.D: A routing protocol to determine best mesh path
options.E: All APs must be the same model

questions.explanation: Mesh networks require: (1) At least one RAP connected to wired network, (2) Dual radios (one for clients, one for mesh backhaul), (3) A routing protocol to find best path through mesh. Different channels should be used for client and backhaul to avoid interference.
questions.exam_tip: Mesh = RAP + MAPs + Dual radios + Routing protocol.
questions.reference: CCNA v1.1 - 1.1d Access Points - MBSS Architecture

questions.question: Which component of split-MAC architecture is responsible for making decisions about client roaming between access points?
questions.explanation: In split-MAC architecture, the WLC handles client association and roaming management. The WLC has visibility into all APs and can facilitate seamless handoffs as clients move between APs.
questions.exam_tip: WLC = Intelligence/Management. AP = Real-time operations.
questions.reference: CCNA v1.1 - 1.1d Access Points - Split-MAC Functions
